title: Can a private student loan with Wells Fargo Bank be included in a Bankruptcy ?
question: Can we discharge a Wells Fargo student loan in bankruptcy?
answers: It is my understanding that you cannot bankrupt on Student Loans. There may be some loopholes, however since the law was revised so much in 2005, I would ask a full-time bankruptcy attorney.

If either you or your daughter filed a Chapter 13 there is a co-debtor stay that would stop all legal action on the Wells Fargo student loan while the debtor is in the bankruptcy. The Chapter 13 plan can be written in such a way to pay the loan through the plan or not pay the loan. There is more flexibility in dealing with student loans in Chapter 13. This Wells Fargo student loan is currently non-dischargeable in any chapter of bankruptcy.

Generally student loans are not dischargeable in bankruptcy. However, if you can show that the Wells Fargo student loans are an "undue hardship" on you and your dependents, then the Court might discharge that debt or a portion of it.

To prove undue hardship you must prove that:
1) You are unable to maintain a "minimal" standard of living;
2) Additional circumstances indicate that this state of affairs will continue to exist for a significant portion of the payment period;
3) You have made a good faith effort to repay the loans.

Additionally, there are other options to assist you in your situation. For example, you may file Chapter 13 bankruptcy to include this Wells Fargo student loan. Although you might not be able to discharge the student loan debt, you can work out a payment plan to your creditors (including the student loan) to reducing the total amount you are currently paying to them combined.

I strongly suggest that you contact an experienced bankruptcy attorney to assist you. There are much more details that need to be addressed and explained with regards to your situation.

I'll add a different spin. First of all, even if your daughter discharges her debt, you are a co-obligor and it won't be discharged as to you. So you'll bear the burden of paying it all.

However, as long as they are current, the bank should not be able to come after you (I'm pretty sure this is true), so there should be some kind of income based repayment that your daughter can apply for so that they don't take too much.

I have friends who make a lot of money but pay like 50-100 per month on student loans. Ask for IBR (income based repayment).

Private student loans are generally not dischargeable in bankruptcy. The exception being a "hardship discharge." In order to qualify, one must basically prove that they suffer from some physical/mentail condition that precludes them from utilizing the education received and therefore have insufficient income or other resources from which to repay the debt. If your daughter is in good health, it is virtually impossible to get rid of this debt. I'm sorry you find yourselves in this position. Something definately needs to be done to provide people like your daughter relief in this situation and to keep others from getting into this mess in the first place.

Protecting private student loans from bankruptcy has done nothing but to encourage lenders making into overly risky loans, while helping push up the cost of college by increasing demand. Sorry, I'll get off my soap box.

Good luck,

Rob Taylor, Esq.
www.affordableattorneysgroup.com

Unless an undue hardship is established, bankruptcy will not discharge a student loan made, insured or guaranteed by a governmental unit or any program funded by same, which constitutes the vast majority of student loans.
